source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: Three different variants of fully recrystallized Zircaloy tube, denoted B, D, and K, were procured from Sandvik AB

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: The three variants were nominally very similar in texture, with the two basal pole maxima tilted about ±30 deg from the radial direction toward the circumferential direction

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: The last step in the thermomechanical treatment was an 80 percent cold reduction in the final rolling followed by a 1.5 h heat treatment at 575°C resulting in complete recrystallization

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: In axial tensile testing of tubular specimens, the B variant had a yield stress (0.2 percent offset) of 160 MPa at 290°C

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: the D variant 182 MPa at 300°C

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: the K variant 213 MPa at 290°C

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: The B and D tubes had a 10.8 mm outside diameter with a 0.72 mm wall thickness

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: The B and D tubes had a 10.8 mm outside diameter with a 0.72 mm wall thickness

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: the K tubes had 12.25 mm and 0.75 mm, respectively

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: the K tubes had 12.25 mm and 0.75 mm, respectively

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: The remaining free length of specimen was 45 mm

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: In some of the B specimens, defects of 1.5 mm in length and with different widths and depths were made by electric-discharge machining on the inside surface

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: a few of the B specimens, subsequently denoted BH, were hydrided to about 90 ppm by weight hydrogen before irradiation

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: literature value of about 50 ppm for the solubility of hydrogen at 300°C

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: Specimens were irradiated at about 285°C in a hot-water loop of the R2 reactor at Studsvik

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: Plane strain burst specimens were irradiated to fast-neutron fluences between 2.4 × 10²⁴ and 10.8 × 10²⁴ n/m², E > 1 MeV

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk1
evidence_span: The irradiated specimens were burst-tested with a heat-resistant oil using a machine that allowed control of the strain rate

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: The maximum internal pressure occurred after 0.3 to 0.6 percent plastic strain

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: The ultimate strength evaluated from the maximum load was in all cases only slightly above the yield stress for all the specimens

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: All specimens failed after some plastic straining

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: The deformation of irradiated specimens is usually very inhomogeneous

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: defects with a depth of up to about 10 percent of the tube wall can be allowed if irradiated Zircaloy cladding will survive 1 percent plastic strain

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: the width of the defect seems to be only of minor importance for irradiated Zircaloy

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: Two types of failure were found. The first type can be described as crack propagation perpendicular to the tube wall, and the second type as shear on a plane at 45 deg to the tube wall

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: Closer examination of the fracture surface shows it to be of a ductile type with dimples

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: This fracture surface appears to be less ductile

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: Failure of the first type was typical of the narrow defects where one would expect a stress concentration effect of the defect, while failure of the second type occurred in specimens with wider defects

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: No incipient cracks were found in the unfailed specimens

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: When using A = 410 MPa, as found by Bement [1]

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: the observed variation in yield stress with fluence around 8×10²⁴ n/m² could not be explained

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: there seems to be a good theoretical foundation for a (ϕt)¹/² dependence at low fluences

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: all values of n between 3 and 6 can be used to give a good description of the data for the irradiated material

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: with n = 6, the yield stress increase at very low fluences predicted by Eq 5 is probably unrealistically rapid

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: For an unirradiated material in a uniaxial test, the influence of defects can be qualitatively understood from a limit load analysis

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk4
evidence_span: σ = (2 σ_y (t-a))/√3 where σ_y = yield stress, t = wall thickness, and a = depth of defect

evidence_span: $\textbf { \textit { m } } =$ $0 . 2 4 + ( 4 . 5 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } ) \sigma .$

evidence_span: Irradiation before stressing decreases primary creep strain of annealed and of cold-worked Zircaloy-2 at stresses above $3 0 0 \bf { M P a }$

evidence_span: Irradiation before stressing decreases primary creep strain of annealed and of cold-worked Zircaloy-2 at stresses above $3 0 0 \bf { M P a }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk6
evidence_span: but slightly increases primary creep of cold-worked Zircaloy-2 below about $2 0 0 \mathbf { M P a }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_013_chunk6
evidence_span: The results of uniaxial creep tests on Zircaloy-2 carried out in research reactors at Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories have been analyzed for primary creep information

evidence_span: only the long-term creep behavior (test times greater than $1 0 0 0 \ \mathrm { h } )$ was discussed
